name: Anna
comment info: This is a global map showing the water stress levels of Urban areas with populations bigger then 3 million and it shows that the places with the most extreme stress were the places that were the most populated (America, India, and China) or places with extreme weather conditions. The places with extreme condition have high water stress because they don’t have enough resources to provide for themselves, also the coutnries with the most populated may have problems because they are trying to comply to many people. I predict that as population continues to grow there will continue to be a higher stress on water.

name: Sunita
comment info: Thank you! My Third Graders are studying the Water Crisis as part of our Transdisciplinary unit "Sharing the Planet". We use this type of questioning to further our students ability to inquiry in greater detail with more meaning.

name: Ireland
comment info: The purpose of graphical display #1 is to help visually show people the water stress levels around the world. The dark red color indicated high stress levels.

name: Anon
comment info:
I noticed that more places closer to the equator have more water stress than places elsewhere.

I wonder if the water shortages also have to do with the heat in those areas. 

Title: Water Stress Crisis

name: Sam Calver-Deckins
comment info: I noticed that Madagascar has a surprisingly high stress level.  There is a clear cluster traveling across the globe north of the equator. I wonder if this is because that is highly populated, although the UK seems to prove otherwise. there is a distinct gap between India and Beijing. a good title would be Stress Levels High.

name: Manuel Hernandez
comment info: I found the map very interested because it gave an easy representation of where water is more scarce all over the world. I live in the north east and i found that water has a low stress level according to the map. I believe this is so because there are more trees in the north east which could play a factor of why water is so accessible. As to the west of the united states water is more scarce because there are not a lot of trees and the air is more dry. I wonder if the countries with more red stress level have a higher cost because the water is limited.

name: Sammi
comment info:
The water is stressed! Read to find out why.
I notice that the highest levels of water stress are in New Delhi, Los Angeles, Beijing. Madrid, Chennai and México City. I also notice that these places are usually in hotter temperatures and drier landscapes. I wonder how they determine how high the water stress levels are. I wonder what variables they take into consideration.

name: Summer Schultz
comment info:
I notice that this map was very carefully made, and it was made to be very understandable. The map was colored to where the lighter yellow is where water shortage is not bad, but then where the red is the water shortage is really really bad. I wonder how the countries that are in the red are feeling right now, I could never imagine what is going through their minds. 

Water is the most essential component to life, it surrounds and makes up our human bodies, to know that there is a crisis happening with the most important resource on earth, that's when we can start to panic. My hope is that we use our resources wisely and we don't take things for granted.

name: Oscar Limon-Zarzosa
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Crisis in H2O

Water is a problem for many countries. And modern times are not different. I noticed that Mexico and India have the most water stress. This is somewhat of a problem since both countries are good trade partners with the US. 

I wonder if this water stress is due to low economies and poverty in both countries.

name: Avery Hodges
comment info:
In this graph I notice that there seem to be a lot of places in the world that are running out of water, and that is very dangerous. Water is essential for us to live, and without it practically every living thing would die off. India and the surrounding ares seem to have this the worst, which is very bad considering the high population in that area. 

This makes me wonder, what happens if/when we run out of water? Will someone create a new filtration system allowing us to be able to consume naturally unsafe water? Or will we not be able to do anything about it and just suffer the consequences?

replies.name: O
replies.location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
replies.comment info: @Avery Hodges, I agree with your sayings that water is essential. To answer your question, these filtration systems are available. They have developed a straw to take in urine and out comes water. These technologies are here, but they are like solar panels: Expensive.

name: Mr. Penguin
comment info:
In Antarctica I don't have to worry about this.
Sincerely,
Mr. W. Penguin

name: @Garrett
comment info: I notice that a lot of hotter climates have more water stress levels in places like Africa. Is this because of the climate or other reasons?

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @@Garrett I also think that this is because of the climate and also the landscape and possibly how populated that area is.

name: William Z
comment info: A lot of regions near the ocean have high water stress level. Why?

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @William Z --

Quite a few of you have mentioned this proximity.  I wonder if there is something about lack of precipitation and oceans?  Or, population density and oceans?  Maybe there are other factors.

What do you think?

name: RD
comment info: A place with lesser tree coverage might have higher water stress.

replies.comment info:
HI, @RD --

How does "A place with lesser tree coverage might have higher water stress" relate to the map?  Give us some examples?  Any counterexamples?

name: Nick P.
comment info: I notice that it is a map of the world and it uses colors ranging from yellow to red to represent the water stress level in a country.  I also notice that there is no correlation between population and water stress level in the top graph. I wonder if there is a reason why South Asia and South Europe have much more water stress than all other areas.  I also wonder why the top graph was included, because it seems like there is no correlation between population and water stress level. I think this is a map of where water stress and scarcity is most prevalent in the world.  A title for this graph could be “Are we running out of water on Earth?”

name: Max
comment info: I notice that there doesn’t seem to be a trend linking water stress levels with population size. But it seems that the places with water stress and large populations, the water stress is amplified. I am curious about what the ten largest cities in the world look like with their water levels. And why did they choose the specific ones they wanted to name? Was that done fairly? Do poorer countries have higher water stress levels?  A possible title could be: the world's biggest cities are being left high and dry.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
@Max Hi!

I also was thinking the same thing about noticing the trend between the water stress levels and the population of a city/country! I also wonder if poorer countries have higher stress levels, that would be a good thing to look into, or to include on the map.

name: James
comment info: Some of these areas may have plenty of water, however, it could be contaminated. Cities in poor regions of the world may not have the sanitation equipment needed to make safe drinking water. Additionally, areas with arid climates have higher water stress than others.

replies.comment info:
HI, @James --

Yours is the first responder to ask if water contamination maybe the problem.

Go to the original report by the World Resource Institute.  There's a link to it in the below Reveal.  Does it mention contamination?  If not, maybe it should.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @James I agree that contamination is a big problem with the water we consume, and not enough people have the proper technology to fix it. What do you think will happen when people realize without the correct filtration systems, the majority of the water will not be safe to consume?

name: Robbie
comment info: I noticed that a lot of areas that are low on water tend to be heavily populated urban cities. For example, Los Angles has a high water stress level. What is the reason for that? Could it be from a lot of people living in close areas? Maybe the weather is a big contribution to the stress levels. I noticed that there are certain parts of Africa that have no data. New York seems to have plenty of water but then Los Angles has a very high-stress level. I believe this is from the weather.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Robbie --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  You say that "a lot of areas that are low on water tend to be heavily populated urban cities."  Where do you see evidence of this?  If it's come the dot graph, take another look at the title.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Robbie I agree a lot of areas where we see high populations have the worst water stress. The reason probably is it is harder to control pollution in cities with a high population because there is so much trash they can't control all of it.

replies.name: W
replies.comment info: @Robbie  Hey Robbie, hope you are well. I agree with what you said about when a city is heavily  populated the water stress level is higher.

name: Alex
comment info: I see in this graph that the larger cities with more than 3 million people are at risk in their water supply. I can assume that these cities are having a tougher time with water supply because they have more people consuming the supply, leading to a larger decrease in water supply, plus a lot of these cities can not properly handle the amount of people they are bringing in on a daily basis in terms of water supply. I think it is time for all of us to realize that water supply is starting to become a real issue in larger cities.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Alex --

Take a look at the projection for water stress worldwide in the coming decades.  You can find this dynamic graph in the article's link that is in the Reveal below the graphs.

name: Trey
comment info: I think that it was very interesting to see how many areas in the US had high water stress levels. It is also easy to observe that most of the areas with high water stress levels are the ones that have higher population. I was also surprised to see that some areas were at a lower risk than most people with think.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Trey --

Which areas have "lower risk than most people would think?"  Why do you think this is the case?

name: Blake
comment info: I think that this graph is referring to how accessible clean water is for people. In many of the dryer and impoverished landscapes that we hear about on the news, there is a higher water stress which causes me to believe that it has to do with accessibility to water for the people of different communities.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Blake I like how you have mentioned on the fact that it is access to clean water not just water in general.  I think even tho there is nothing that says that is it talking about clean useable water it is still good to inquire that the data may be talking about useable water.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Blake I agree. The climate has a lot to do with how much water is there. If the city is in a desert, they may not have an excess of water.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Blake I agree with your point about water accessibility. Have you considered the wildfires and environment where this water is under high stress? If the graph was showing accessibility you would see more red in Africa and less in North America.

name: Thomas
comment info: Looking at the graph I noticed that the majority of the areas with extremely high water stress levels are in areas that have dry or hot climates. A lot more has to be done to get water to these people in these places because there is not naturally enough there for more than 3 million people in most cases. In New York they have a lot of people, but the climate in that area makes it so that water is more abundant. There is also some areas with no data collected so I would wonder what those areas would look like if they were filled in. It doesn't seem to really matter the status of the country, it seems like there is water stress all over the world.

name: Hunter
comment info: It seems like areas with denser populations have a higher water stress area than areas with a seemingly less concentrated population. I wonder if the average temperature of these areas also factors into the amount of water stress, when the population is taken into consideration of course.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Hunter I agree with you and I also think that the average temperature in these areas has a big effect on the degree of water stress. For example Los Angeles is mostly humid, with almost no rain which makes sense because it has such as high water stress level.

name: Doug
comment info: When I first looked at the graph, I was drawn to how not all of the map was colorized, and I am curious why this is. The graph says it is because the population in those areas isn't 3 million, but I would imagine that if you set the start at 3 million people that the data could be skewed. The southwest US and coast of west Mexico are all red, and I wonder if that has to do with the climate or just how stressed the water is. I don't think that a factor is wealth distribution but I do think that the amount of people in the area does affect the water stress.

name: Emery
comment info: One of things that caught my attention is how most of the areas in the middle along the equator have a much higher water stress level then places higher or lower. This is probably because the higher heat along these areas.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Emery Thats what I said, I mentioned that the equator seems to have a big impact on where the water apeared to be going the fastest. Especially in heavily populated areas.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Emery I agree with you because, along the equator, there seem to be the highest stress levels of water. It may be because of how humid it is and due to the massive population size in some of those areas, such as Los Angelos, that has around 12 million individuals. Even when comparing it to New Dehli with the same stress levels of water, it has an even larger population size of approximately 28 million. I wonder if both factors, weather and population size in those areas, cause regions near the equator to have such enormous stress levels of water.

name: Paxton
comment info: The correlation between higher populated cities and extreme water stress is present.  My question is why do some countries not have data?  Was it so low it was unable to be calculated or is there some other reasoning?  Is there a way for anything to be resolved?

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Paxton Hey Paxton, hope all is well. I was actually wondering the same thing you were. I was also wondering why some countries are picked out and some aren't. An example of this is how Atlanta is outed and some other states/countries are while some aren't. I was also curious about what this does and if there is anything we can do to resolve this issue.

name: Skylar S.
comment info: I noticed that the stress in water levels is based on population GREATER than 3 million, which makes me wonder what the graph would look like if it included places with under 3 million people. I was very surprised to see that a lot of the U.S was low to medium on stress levels, which is interesting to me because I feel like we are a pretty wasteful country. I was also surprised to see that most of Australia do not have any data collected, which makes me wonder how they even collected this data.

name: Alex
comment info: It's hard to find a consistent pattern but it seems that the more populated urban areas with a hot and dry climate have the highest water stress. California struggles greatly with drought for most of the year while because it is so hot and dry. On the other hand, New York has one of the lowest water stress levels because its climate is the opposite of California's.

name: Josh
comment info: I found it interesting how the west coast was very high water stress but south america and canada was very low. I can see that the south and the North had the lowest stress but towards the middle it was very high. Africa didn’t have enough data for a lot of the countries which means that a lot of the stress was very low in those areas. What would the graph look like if the population was under 3 million?

name: Gracie
comment info: From this graph I notice that the West side of the US seems to have more of a water scarcity problem compared to the East Coast, specifically California. California has been in a drought for years now, and I am concerned the fact that we aren't doing a ton about it. But what also concerns me is the fact that big cities other than places in the US are also having issues and we aren't hearing about it. Places like Mexico City or New Delhi or Chennai are also places of extremely high water stress levels. I wonder what we can do about it to help these hugely populated places get better. A caption for this would be "Water Stress Levels adds to Human Stress Level."

name: Clayton
comment info: I think the graph has to do with populations. The higher the population in an area the higher the "water stress"  levels will be. This explains why India is so red. Because of there population they must use a lot of water to keep up with the people needing it for bathing, washing, drinking etc. .

name: Patrick C.
comment info: I believe the graph is showing the water stress level, or how much water a country is in need of water. The water stress level indicates how much water a country has in the first place, and how in need they are of fresh water. My title for the graph would be, “Where’s your water”

name: Grant
comment info: This graph is showing the water stress levels throughout the world. This graph is showing that the south west of the U.S. has an extremely high stress level along with India. While the data taken from Africa shows that most of Africa does not have an extremely high stress level compared to India and the south west U.S.

name: Evan
comment info: On this map, the cities with the highest population density are the ones with less water security due to the fact that they have more mouths to feed. Even the wealthier countries struggle with water security like the US and parts of Canada and Russia. This is because even though they have the money to afford a ton of water they still have a high population of people that need it. I wonder what "Water stress level" means. Is it, amount of water storage? The ability to supply water if the water they bring runs out? Or something different. My headline would be, The Struggle to Supply Water to Millions of People.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Evan --

Good question:  What does 'water stress level' mean?  

In The Reveal below the graphs and map, you'll find a link to the report from the World Resource Institute that released this information.  There, you will find their definition of water stress level.

name: Joe Goldberg
comment info: "Eye- catching water levels" I noticed that a lot of areas that are lacking water tend to be the heavily populated urban areas. Therefore, there is a lot of production happening causing pollution. I wonder why New York has an abundance of water due to the trend of heavily populated areas having high water stress levels. Some of the water levels may be due to climate such as California is a very dry desert area for the most part and New York is the opposite. It is hard to decipher a pattern in the graph due to the variation of the abundance of water in certain urban areas versus rural areas. Overall the map encompasses the idea that something has to change with our system on preserving water or else some parts of the world will run out.

name: Corey
comment info: When I looked at this graph, I noticed that most of the areas of high water stress levels are areas with hot, dry climates (such as the SW United States, Mexico, and India.) Another thing I noticed was that a lot of the places in dark red have sociopolitical and/or economic issues, such as Spain due to the Catalan Independence Movement that threatens to be civil war, and the less said about the truckload of Middle Eastern conflict the better. I wonder how imperialism and capitalism as it relates to the commodification of basic necessities has affected these issues. When I look here, the US, one of the most capitalist countries on the planet, as well as the proverbial Evil Empire has a surprisingly high level of water stress. Also, notice how red India is. I am positive that colonization has something to do with this. I also wonder how much of this is simply due to government incompetence, which has to be factored in. if i were to  make a catchy headline to describe what is going on in the graph, I would title it "Let Them Drink Water".

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: I agree. I think that the graph correlates to the landscape and accessibility to water. Many of the countries that have a dryer environment, seem to be on the higher end of the stress level.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info:
@Corey 
Interesting inferences, I did not think about some of things that you said that should have come to my mind. Climate is definitely a huge factor since you can see New York is fine on water supply but LA is struggling.

Good morning, @Corey --

You raise some very interesting and provocative ideas.  You may want to ask -- did the political situation result in water stress?  Or, did water stress result in a political conflict?  Of, course, this may vary from region to region.

name: Keith
comment info: What stuck out to me the most about this graph is America’s west coast. If these trends continue, which is probably going to be the case, it wouldn’t be hard to imagine a large migration. The other thing I noticed was that South America’s water stress levels are low compared to other places on the map. I predict in the future that people who are in these red areas southwest of The U.S. will begin to look for water elsewhere, maybe even from the continent right below.

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: @Keith Interesting point, it's hard to imagine what sort of impacts this could have on the population over time

name: Danielle
comment info: while looking at the graph, the higher stress levels seem to be located in areas that are typically very dry along the west coast of the United States. These areas seem to not have very drastic season changes like New York, so I wonder if that has to do with something. For instance, New York experiences four different seasons and each year the seasons bring either more snow, less snow, less rain, more rain, more droughts... So I wonder if this graph could indicate a potential trend for water levels of 2020, but may not be permeant.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Danielle I agree that areas that are generally thought of as dry have a water shortage. I wonder how our perspective would change if we had a map that colored all land but the water shortage was compared to the population of that region. I also wonder about rising water levels, but I wonder why places so close to the coast still have water shortages.

name: Victoria
comment info: I noticed that India seems to have extremely high water stress levels which leads me to wonder if this has something to do with companies such as Coca-Cola using the water sources of small villages, such as Kala Dera, to fill their Dasani water bottles. It raises this question because it has been an issue with environmentalists that the water of small villages is being wrongfully tapped into by bigger companies leaving the citizens of these villages with little to no water for themselves. Im curious to know if situations like these have any contribution to the data on this graph.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Victoria Wow, this is a very interesting but great observation, I did not even realize how scarce the water amount is in India, I believe that the companies in India do contribute to this risk, but also individual usage along with just at home daily water use.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Victoria I think that your comment brings up an interesting point about how big corporations affect the water supply. Large corporations have a lot of factories over in Asia because they can find cheap labor and I wonder if this affects the water stress at all. I also think that areas like California and Mexico are in the red because of their natural dry climate and over population.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Victoria I like that you mentioned large companies like Coca-Cola are using these water sources from small villages. I didn't take the route of bigger companies being behind the excess of water. I went behind more of the government route.

name: Morgan Faery
comment info: When I first looked at this graph, I recognized most cities that had high water stress levels were heavily populated. It was seen that there was more heavily populated areas at a high water stress levels then not, with the exception of New York. However, when the global map was looked at, there was no clear trend. Most of the areas with high water stress levels are located near large masses of water. I find this strange and feel that there is a underlying, correlated reason for this. Also, it seems that it is more of high water stress levels in warmer areas, than not.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Morgan Faery --

You wonder whether water stress is affected by population, location near large masses of water, or temperature.  What other factors may be affecting water stress?  

Think about both the supply of water and the demand for water.

name: Marie
comment info:
I first looked at the eye-catching red areas and noticed that they are mostly associated with arid climates: Western US and Western Central America, the Middle East. However, this is not true with the two red areas in India and China. India has monsoons and Northeastern China also is a monsoon-like climate. This means that the water shortage for these countries is either because of a negative change in the monsoon pattern or extremely high population destination. 
It would also be interesting to know if water stress looks at both the lack of water and the contamination of water. Places like Flint, Michigan at one point had no clean water and that information should be included in this water stress graph to better analyze water availability.

name: David
comment info: I notice a few troubling patterns here regarding which urban areas of the world tend to fall under the worst categories of water stress. Locations such as California, Spain, India, northeastern China, and Australia have both very well-developed and/or rapidly-expanding economies, and all of them appear to contain large swaths of areas with worryingly-high water stress levels. For the most part, this seems logically-sound, as these already-densely populated regions (many of which are still gaining in citizenry) obviously place a high demand on the environment’s freshwater supply; it’s well-known that wealthier societies usually have much higher ecological footprints than those that are still in the developing phase. Anyhow, and although economic inequality between countries is currently declining, the apparent fact that the water stress severity in otherwise increasingly-prosperous areas like China and India is already as intense as many developed societies may ultimately hinder the push for greater equity and mutual prosperity amongst humanity’s many outposts around the world...

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @David --

Is water stress a source of crisis in some regions that increases migration and armed conflict?  This makes it more than a local concern.   Are we focusing enough on this in world forums?

name: Kevin
comment info: I noticed that many of the high water stress levels are taking place in extremely populated areas, such as Los Angeles or Italy. Aside from the fact these places are heavily populated, most of these regions face brutal heat and dry spells. I would not consider this a crisis, however, because there is a good majority of areas with a low stress level with a naturing environment. If these regions help others, a balance could be found to restore the stress levels.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Kevin I agree with your interpretation of the graph; the denser the population the more stress there is on water levels. Some areas are in rougher conditions than others but we can definitely make an impact on this.

name: Ashlee
comment info: According to the graph the areas with the highest water stress levels are generally known as the more dryer regions of the world. Not only are they experiencing higher temperatures they are also experiencing less rain. Areas such as California, Mexico, and the Arabian Peninsula are suffering in part to those two factors. These factors mixed with the high population result in an insufficient water supply posing a threat to those who reside in those regions as well as a global one. It would be interesting for this to be surveyed again now as global warming is affecting climate change at a rapid rate. Continents such as Australia must currently be experiencing extreme high levels of water stress as the bush fires are decimating their land.

name: Ian Condon
comment info: I noticed that the water stress levels of a city have to do with both the income and climate of the city. For example, both New Delhi and Los Angeles have extremely high water stress levels because New Delhi has a lot of poor people, Los Angeles is very dry, and Mexico City is both poor and dry. New York, on the other hand, is in a very temperate climate and has a higher median income than the extremely high water stress level cities (New York with a median income of $50,125 and Mexico City with $13,220). So I don't think that we have anything to worry about because this graph is not showing what the levels are over time. Yes, water stress levels are high in some big cities, but it is also low in others.

name: Clara
comment info: Why the cities near the sea have a high water stress?

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: @Clara Sea water would not count in this since it is not drinkable water. The process of turning salt water into fresh water is very expensive and difficult so it is not an easy solution as of now for this problem.

name: Alexa
comment info:
I noticed...

I thought when first looking at this graph that it was only densely populated areas that were at risk of running out of water, but upon closer inspection it seems to be a combination of high population and a drier climate. In my mind it makes sense that Los Angeles would be at a higher risk of running out of water than New York because even though both cities have large populations, only LA has a dry, hot climate.

I wondered...

It seems to me that this graph seems a little daunting about our water situation, but this graph doesn't seem to show how the amount of water in these areas has changed over time. To me, this means that maybe the water crisis isn't a crisis after all and could possibly have remained the same for hundreds of years (when factoring in population growth).

Catchy title...

Water Stress? We May Need a Bigger Stress Ball...

replies.name: C
replies.comment info:
@Alexa 
I like your opinion. i never thought the water stress would be issue, since we have so many advanced techology. We cna easily use recycle water.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Alexa I find it very interesting the fact that you point out that this might not be a water crisis at all. It was a good point to point out that it doesn't show us the change over time. I also wonder how we could figure out what is causing these immense stress levels, but more so how to prevent it from rising even further.

name: Adelaide
comment info: I noticed that the area with the most water stress was near the Middle East, India, and Asia. I was surprised to see that Africa, which is mostly dry land was not as water-deprived as other places. The United States also seems to be having high water stress levels near California. I also noticed that Chennai and Los Angeles have an extremely high chance of running out of water. New York is at low risk for running out of water. I'm wondering if losing water is more of a risk now in more populated places because there are more people that need water resources. I also wonder how we get more water resources around the globe. A title I would choose for this graph is Water for the Win.

name: Maddy
comment info: I noticed that areas that have the highest water stress levels are south-west North America and Central Asia. I wonder if these places naturally have a low amount of water, or if it is being used up because of the big population. I also noticed that New York has a very very low water stress level, even though it is highly populated. I wonder if this has to do with the amount of snow or precipitation, and if not, what factors have caused low water stress levels. I also noticed that the states in the top of Africa have no data, but they are areas that are low on water. I wonder why they did not get data from these areas.

replies.comment info: @Maddy Great noticings. Could you summarize your ideas in a catchy headline?

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Maddy  I like all of your ideas. I also thought that why is New York very populated and has a low water stress level. While another very populated city across the country has a very high water stress level. I believe that this is from the weather. In California, they have many droughts and wildfires.

name: Kaiya
comment info:
My claim is that if you live in a densely populated area with a dry aired climate there are extremely high water stress levels.

My warrant is India and Los Angeles are an example of high water stress levels and dry climate.

replies.comment info: @Kaiya Interesting! Are there any populated areas with arid climates that are not red on this graph?

name: Brigid
comment info:
What I noticed -

I noticed that in the U.S the places in which there was the most red was in the arid areas of the U.S. I noticed in Mexico there is a lot of red which is probably because Mexico is mostly desert. I also noticed that the places in the Middle East area and India are the planes with the highest water stress level. I noticed the continents with the lowest water stress level were Africa and South America.

What I wondered -

I wondered why Africa didn't have a higher level of water stress because it is a very arid area. Maybe it is because of the fact that it is harder for the locals to get clean water so they don't use the water in the area for fear of infection. I was also surprised to hear that New York was in the low stress level because there are so many people in New York City I thought they would at least be in the low to medium range.

name: Amber and Nicole
comment info: My claim is that the warmer the weather the more the water is stressed and visa versa, my warrant is because the warmer places would use more water than colder states and colder states usually gain more water naturally.

replies.comment info:
@Amber and Nicole 
I'm curious about the exceptions to this. Parts of Canada are red, for example. How does the change your argument?

name: Yoyo
comment info: High population causes pollutions and lack of water resources

replies.name: P
replies.comment info: @Yoyo I agree, I believe this is due to the size of the population usurping and exhausting most of the countries resources. In the future, the government could do something to monitor how much water each country is using and then attempt to fix our water crisis from this.

replies.name: P
replies.comment info:
@Yoyo 

Is there another way that this can be tracked?  Look at the correlation between dryer climates and extremely high risk for water loss.

name: Louis
comment info: The country which has more population causes more water stress and pollution

name: Louis
comment info: Because the altitude of Los Angeles is lower than Atlanta, the water stress level from higher altitude is relatively low.

name: Anne
comment info: Those red places seem to have high populations and high populations caused pollution.

replies.comment info: @Anne How do Tokyo and NYC play into your argument (since they are not red)?

name: Marie
comment info:
I noticed that overall there are low/ low-medium water stress levels. However, I found this strange as water is told to be becoming more and more scarce due to an increase in demand/ consumption and global warming. I noticed that many countries in Asia are at a high risk of water stress along with the USA and Italy. 

I wonder how accurate the data provided is though as many locations have "no data". This includes countries in Africa of which we are aware have generally already a high water scarcity. In addition, other countries in Africa such as, the Democratic Republic of the Congo seem to have "low" water stress levels which is strange as much of Africa has a lack of access to water and therefore, I would expect it to at least have a "medium to high" water stress level.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Marie You have some really great observations! I also found it interesting how there was a great deal of missing information in the graph. I really liked how you applied the graph to what was happening in the world. Overall great job!

name: Ms.Hamrick's Class
comment info: We noticed that all of the comments are very scientific.  The red is in a similar location across the map.  We wonder why there is no data at the top of Africa.  The map looks like it is in the shape of a kangaroo.  There are a lot of different colors on the countries.  We think the colors are related to heat because they are warm colors.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Ms.Hamrick's Class because they don't have the advanced technical machine to measure the pollution of the water or maybe their government doesn't want to show their data

name: Jack
comment info:
"Geographical impacts on Water"
Seeing the graph, I wonder what people could do to help combat water shortages in areas around the world. In places such as California, particularly Los Angeles the water levels are extremely high. I wonder if this is due to an abundance of agriculture. In California, they grow almonds which need one-thousand nine hundred gallons of water to produce one pound of almonds. In the mid west the levels of water stress are medium to high levels of water stress because of Ogallala Aquifer losing water due to farmers using it at a higher level than the aquifer can replace. Unlike cities such as New York City, the abundance of snow and precipitation help to replenish wells and other sources of water. New York State has laws in place that protect the Finger Lakes which are the second largest source of freshwater in the world. By protecting the water supply, they are able to protect it from contamination and allow it to replenish. In India, the country seems to be in a constant level of high water stress. This is due to government corruption and lack of planning to filter out water from human waste. The graph is showing a combination of location, and financial situations and how they affect the water level stresses in major areas.

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Jack --

I think you have hit on something!  Water stress can be cause by too much demand.  Or, too little supply.  Or, both.

How about creating a catchy headline that combines your two approaches to water stress?

name: Amanda W.
comment info: It appears that the areas with extremely high water stress levels are located in Southwest North America and Central Asia. There are several possibilities why these areas are suffering more than others. One reason may be overpopulation. Asia is the highest populated continent on the planet, which means greater competition for water resources among humans and wildlife. Another reason for water scarcity may be geographical location. Southwestern North America consists highly of desert terrain unlike the Northeast, which consists of grassland surrounded by large bodies of water.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Amanda W. --

Want to create a headline that combines your two noticings?  Please share with us.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Amanda W. I agree with the location of water stress levels and I also thought about how population plays in this. Your geography skills are very accurate. With all that you have noticed, I bet if you created a catchy title it will strengthen your argument!

name: Charlotte
comment info:
Hi there!

My group and I noticed that the red marks indicated extremely high stress levels of water in Urban Areas with a population bigger than 3 million whereas, the lighter yellow colour indicates a lower stress level of water access. We notice that Los Angeles is in a very high water stress level zone which makes us worried for our own future and how we are going to be able to get clean access to water in the future! We were surprised to see that Los Angeles' stress level for water access is higher than for Mexico City.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Charlotte and her group --

Take another look at the dot graph labels, especially the horizontal axis.  Does it  show that “Los Angeles' stress level for water access is higher than for Mexico City?”  Or something else?

replies.name: M

name: Evan & Nadia & Amalea
comment info: We notice that the areas with a dessert terrain and a high population leads to a high water stress. The need for water is at a high demand therefore the an increase of droughts will occur.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Evan & Nadia & Amalea --

Here's another idea.  Climate change results in more variability in weather and more intense weather.  How would this affect water stress in desert and high population areas?

comment info:

Only thing, i'm not quite sure of what I should be taking away. Through confusion with colors and not enough background information is this data good or bad? should be be scared? Is New York okay for geographical reasons or attitude reasons?

replies.name: D
replies.comment info:
@Gianna Lotman 
I agree with your comment, and it is hard to understand what exactly the graph is trying to represent or even communicate.

name: Mia and Kenzie
comment info: We are wondering how water quality affects water stress levels within Urban Areas?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mia and Kenzie --

That’s a great wonder.  I wonder how water quality and water quantity could be shown on a graph together.  Any ideas?

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Mia and Kenzie I think because of the high populations in those urban cities can cause pollution and lack of water resources.

name: Gwendolyn
comment info: I am thinking about how Cape Town is not identifiable on the graph in the high to extremely high water stress levels, considering the water crisis they experienced fairly recently. This makes me wonder if extreme water stress is a fixable problem, or not. Because Cape Town is relatively small in comparison to Los Angeles and other extremely high water-stress levels, would that explain how it was not a permanent situation? Or is this a dangerous mindset to have concerning climate change?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Gwendolyn --

You are right that Cape Town is no identified on the graph!  It’s in the middle of the dots on the left of the High water-stress line graph.  I guess not enough room to write all of the cities’ names.  You can see all of the cities’ names in the article that included this graph.  We’re release it tomorrow.

But you have hit on something else.  Climate change results in more variability in weather and more intense weather.  Take Australia.  It had drought with the resulting fires.  Now, it has downpours.  Where else has this happened (closer to home)?

name: Zoe
comment info: I notice that places in Europe and Asa have the most extremely high water stress levels. The U.S has a lot as well( high to extremely high water stress levels).It seems that most of the U.S's higher water stress levels are in the west to midwest and less in the east. It appears that Canada and South America have the least water stress levels. I wonder why Greenland and large patches of Africa are undocumented? Why do you think this is happening?

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Zoe I think that this is just what is happening when countries have large urban areas in places without good access to water. It seems like most of the areas with really high water stress seem to be along the same latitude. I wonder how much more the size of the urban areas affects water stress than the placement of the city.

name: Moderator CL
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  “Water Woes” by Mrs. S.’s class in Shoal Lake, Manitoba, Canada, and "Effects of Urbanization on Availability of Water" by Abby of Michigan.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, January 23 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released tomorrow – Thursday, January 23, with moderation on Wednesday, January 29.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  The topic --  sports injuries.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph.

The link for the Stat Nuggets archives ishttps://tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, whose city’s Deer Island Waste Water Treatment Plant has cleaned up one of the dirtiest harbors in the U. S. and given us more usable water, and Chris Luzniak of Los Angeles, who is going to engage his students at The Archer School in further debate on the best ways to lower water stress in Southern California.

name: Bradley
comment info: I was thinking about how it seems California seems to have been in a water drought for quite some time now. I remember a few years back how the issue was all over the news, and it caused human stress levels to rise because of the water stress levels. I wonder how and why many news sources haven't included places like Mexico City or New Delhi into the talks of potentially running dry. The populations of both of these cities are over 20 million, where the L.A. population is roughly 12 million according to the chart. Water stress levels are rising in many areas and should be acknowledged and addressed by everyone from all across the globe.

replies.comment info: @Bradley Great point. Can you summarize this in a catchy headline?

name: Amelia
comment info: Seeing this, I wonder what we can do to counter the water shortages in major cities around the world. I have noticed that cities such as LA, New Delhi, Mexico City, and Cape Town are maroon. This means that the water stress (water scarcity) levels are extremely high. On the other hand, cities like New York and Reykjavik have low stress levels. Both cities rain/snow constantly and are relatively more water conservative. They both have great water way systems, and in Iceland the water is heated by geothermal power plants. Cities that have high water scarcity levels, are in some cases financially poorer. On the other hand, Africa for the most part, has low or no data collected, yet areas near the Sahara are orange or red. In conclusion, this graph is a combination of Geological location, financial situation, and quality of system in the area.

replies.comment info: @Amelia Great insights! Can you summarize this with a catchy headline?

name: Emma
comment info:
I noticed that the countries with the highest water stress seem to be in the region above the Tropic of Cancer, this surprises me as I would have assumed the countries closest to the equator (some of the warmest countries) would have had a higher water stress. 
Broadly speaking, however, these countries seem to have a lower water stress level. 

I am also curious as to how this data was collected because Sub Saharan Africa seems to have low water stress according to the map. In my geography class I learned that some of these countries are suffering from desertification due to lack of water, therefore, it confuses me to see their water stress levels so low.

replies.comment info:
@Emma- Great insight in reference to the Tropic of Cancer. 

Good question about Sub Saharan Africa. I wonder if the gray areas are places that did not have data submitted. Stay tuned for more info in The Reveal tomorrow!

replies.name: Z
replies.comment info: @Emma The fact that Africa has one of the lowest water stress levels confuses me too.

name: Vic
comment info: It is apparent to me that the most affected areas are in regions of the highest populations, such as: California, NYC, India, etc. and some of these areas may have lower economic status. This may factor into how people make decisions on where to live based on the potential water crisis, as well as the people currently living in these areas having to make decisions about conserving water and making sure their water is clean.

replies.comment info:
@Vic - Good point that this data cold affect decisions on where to live. 

I'm curious about NYC. I notice it in the Low category. How is it different from California and India?

replies.name: Z
replies.comment info: @Vic I thought Italy was flooding but it is almost completely red?

name: Emma
comment info: I wonder how they collected this data!

comment info: In the graph, it seems to be showing the most polluted or at risk bodies of water around the world. For example: New Dehli, India, has the highest pollution it looks like. This make sense because India is known to be one of the most polluted countries in the world.

Hi @Chloe E!
Can you talk more about your pollution data? Are you saying that is what the graph shows or something you are referencing based on other data? Can you share a link?

comment info: I notice that certain countries/regions don’t have any colors to indicate water stress levels. I wonder why those countries don’t have any data. Also, Hi Mr. Luz! This is Emily D. from Archer’s Statistics Section 1!

@Emily-
Can you make any conjectures about why some of those countries might not have any colors?

replies.name: A

Places like Greenland have such small populations that it would be quite hard to study. Oddly, Iceland has less than 400,000 residents, but there is data collected on the country. It also could be with geological location and how easy areas are to access.

replies.name: Z
replies.comment info: @Emily The graph states that the gray area is undocumented, why I am not sure. Possibly it is  because they don't have a big enough population. The graph says water stress levels of urban areas with a population bigger than 3 million.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Some of these cities are approaching Day Zero, when their water supply goes dry.  

Read more about how cities try to not reach Day Zero at:https://tinyurl.com/ZeroDayZero

name: Cole
comment info: I noticed that there is a lot of red in India and the US which makes sense to me. I wonder what would happen if our population got to its maximum capacity. I bet the graph would look different. In this graph, it is spreading awareness about the water crisis going on and who is being affected most by it.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Cole --
Thank you for your noticings.  What does red signify?  Where else is there red?  
The causes for extremely high-water crisis vary.  Pick two different areas in the world that are experiencing extremely high-water crisis and wonder why they are having this problem.  The problems may be for very different reasons.

name: Abby Vitale
comment info: I noticed that large cities in the west in the US and towards the middle of Eurasia are experiencing extremely high water stress levels. Cities like Los Angeles, Mexico City, and New Delhi with very high populations are at risk of running out of water. I wonder why these specific areas are experiencing water shortages and not cities like New York and Atlanta. Most of Africa even has low water stress. This graph is showing the trend of how population affects the level of water stress in a specific area. A headline that could fit this graph could be, "Effects of Urbanization on Availability of Water".

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Abby Vitale --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings that give evidence to your claims.  
There are a few very underpopulated areas that have water stress.  Where are they?  
I would say that there are very different reasons for water scarcity.  Some have to do with supply of water.  Some have to do with demand of water.  Some have to do with both.  You may want to classify the cities or regions into these three categories.
And, thank you for your headline.

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph and map show the water stress levels for cities with populations greater than 3 million and where in the world there is the prospect of running out of water.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph and the map. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these visual representations and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, January 23, 2020 with moderation on Wednesday, January 29.  The topic – sports injuries.  Stay tuned.

name: Sean
comment info:
1. I noticed that most of the highest populated areas were experiencing water droughts. 
2. I wondered why other very populated areas such as New York City were not as affected by the water droughts. 
3. In this graph, it's bringing to attention the mass drought that is taking place all over the world.

replies.comment info:
Good moring, @Sean --

Thank you for noticing and wondering.  Let me ask you – what is your evidence that “the highest populated areas were experiencing water droughts?”  I wonder if there are low population areas that have water crises?  Can you find any?

name: Clair
comment info: While I was looking at this graph, I noticed a trend correlating between the population and the amount of water present in these locations. I wonder, however, why some areas are low on water supply, considering there are located near a large body of water, like California. It's also confusing why some areas that you'd think would be suffering are not. In this graph, we are presented with water stress levels throughout the entire world and how extreme the stress is.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Clair --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  Would you please give us evidence that there is “a trend correlating between the population and the amount of water present in these locations?”  Are there examples where this isn’t true?  

Regarding your wonder about water scarcity for areas near large bodies of water, like oceans.  How can people use ocean water for drinking and agriculture?  

How about a catchy headline that captures the main ideas of the graph or map?

name: Allie
comment info: Most countries with water loss are more southern. I wonder if there is a correlation between population and water supply. I am curious how places closest to the coast have an extreme water problem. The graph shows water availability vs demand. The graph shows how dangerous the stress levels are.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Allie --

You say that “Most countries with water loss are more southern.”  Would you please explain what you mean by “southern?”  Why do you think this is the case?

name: Sophia
comment info: I noticed that most countries that have a high water stress level are above the equator. I wonder why that is because all areas that are red are near water; therefore they should somehow use the ocean to turn into useful fresh water. This graph shows water stress levels throughout the world. It shows which areas are in the most danger due to lack of water and which areas are not.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Sophia --

Several of your classmates have noticed and wondered that “most countries that have a high-water stress level are above the equator” and “why that is because all areas that are red are near water.”  Maybe an online search about using ocean water for drinking and agriculture would respond to your wonderings.  I hope you or your classmates would share what you find.

name: Mrs. S
comment info: My attention was drawn to Canada since that is where I live. I am very surprised to see extreme water stress in southern Manitoba and Saskatchewan. I wonder what factors are considered in determining water stress. Populations there are low and there are lots of fresh water lakes.  What is creating water stress? I wonder if the need for water for agriculture has had a significant impact. Does the water stress level change significantly over drought years and years with heavier annual rainfall? Are high phosphorus levels in fresh water lakes due to poor water treatment and agricultural run off considered in calculating water stress? In noticing the extremely high water stress levels around the globe I am lead to wonder: What water sources are available to areas with high water stress? What alternative water sources are being explored? A significant portion of areas with water stress are coastal. What progress is being made to make desalinating water more plausible on a large scale? What different stress factors are considered? I wonder if there are any obvious patterns linking urban areas with high populations and low stress levels? or with high stress levels? "Water Woes"

replies.comment info:
Thank you, @Mrs. S’s class, from Shoal Lake, Manitoba.  

You wonder why there would be water scarcity in Manitoba with all of its fresh-water lakes.  I did a quick online search and found that the reason may be due, in part, to poor watershed management.  That could include many different factors.  Search online to learn more.  

Please return tomorrow to get the graph and map’s Reveal at the bottom of the release.  There, we share the article that included these graphs plus much more.  The article addresses your wonders and gives you links to other resources.

How about a headline that captures your ideas?

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
@Mrs. S 
You bring up some very interesting questions that caught my eye. I also wonder what alternative water sources can be explored. I also wonder why there are some very populous cities, such as New York and Atlanta, that aren't experiencing these stress levels. Also, what would the graph look like if they took data for places with under 3 million people?
